title: Nigeria PIT Audit Guide
text: Meet Mr. Garba, diligent Taraba Internal Revenue Service (TIRS) tax auditor. Mr. Garba tasked conducting Pay---Earn (PAYE) audit Infosights Consulting, software company Jalingo, Nigeria.

title: Nigeria PIT Audit Guide
text: Mr. Garba arrives Infosights Consulting sunny Monday morning audit checklist friendly smile. company’s accountant, Ms. Nyayokli, greets . “Good morning, Mr. Garba. ’ve expecting . Please, come .” Mr. Garba begins reviewing company’s payroll records, searching discrepancies anomalies.

title: Nigeria PIT Audit Guide
text: Mr. Garba works, approached several employees questions concerns tax deductions.

title: Nigeria PIT Audit Guide
text: “Excuse , Mr. Garba. hope can help clarify something. One employees, Mr. Ademola, complaining tax deductions. says ’s -taxed. Can explain tax deductions work?” Garba sits company’s accountant, HR Manager, Ms. Nyayokli, Ms. Francisca respectively, begins review salary components one employees, Mr. Ademola.

title: Nigeria PIT Audit Guide
text: “Let’s start Mr. Ademola’s gross salary,” Garba says. ’ll use gross_salary() function nigeriaPITaudit package calculate .” Gross salary refers total earnings (e.g., basic salary, allowances, bonuses, overtime pay, etc.) employment. Garba opens R console loads nigeriaPITaudit package. Ms. Francisca, record shows Mr. Ademola annual basic salary 500000, allowances 150000, bonuses 200000. item included, overtime pay? Just sure included. Ms. Francisca: “salary last year include overtime pay.” Garba: “Okay, let’s see total gross salary .”
code: library(nigeriaPITaudit) gross <- gross_salary(basic_salary = 500000, allowances = 150000, bonuses = 200000) print(noquote(format(gross, big.mark = ",", scientific = FALSE))) #> [1] 850,000

title: Nigeria PIT Audit Guide
text: “Next, ’ll calculate Mr. Ademola’s tax exemptions,” Garba says. “include pension deduction, NHF deduction, NHIS deduction.” Ademola contribute ? Section 3(1): employee shall, purpose pension contributions, pensionable salary, determined basic salary may include emolument allowance agreed employer employee, stipulated employer’s policy.
code: pension <- pension_deduction(gross, rate = 0.08) nhf <- nhf_deduction(basic_salary = 500000, rate = 0.025) nhis <- nhis_deduction(gross, rate = 0.05)  list(   Pension = noquote(format(pension, big.mark = ",", scientific = FALSE)),   nhf = noquote(format(nhf, big.mark = ",", scientific = FALSE)),   bhis = noquote(format(nhis, big.mark = ",", scientific = FALSE)) ) #> $Pension #> [1] 68,000 #>  #> $nhf #> [1] 12,500 #>  #> $bhis #> [1] 42,500

title: Nigeria PIT Audit Guide
text: “Now, ’ll calculate Mr. Ademola’s gross income subtracting tax exemptions gross salary,” Garba explains.
code: grossIncome <- gross_income(gross, pension, nhf, nhis) print(noquote(format(grossIncome, big.mark = ",", scientific = FALSE))) #> [1] 727,000

title: Nigeria PIT Audit Guide
text: “Next, ’ll calculate Mr. Ademola’s consolidated relief,” Garba says. “based gross income.” CRA calculated :
code: consolidatedRelief <- consolidated_relief(grossIncome, period = "yearly") print(noquote(format(consolidatedRelief, big.mark = ",", scientific = FALSE))) #> [1] 345,400

title: Nigeria PIT Audit Guide
text: “Now, ’ll calculate Mr. Ademola’s total relief adding consolidated relief tax exemptions,” Garba explains.
code: totalRelief <- total_relief(consolidatedRelief, pension, nhf, nhis) print(noquote(format(totalRelief, big.mark = ",", scientific = FALSE))) #> [1] 468,400

title: Nigeria PIT Audit Guide
text: “Finally, ’ll calculate Mr. Ademola’s taxable income subtracting total relief gross salary,” Garba says.
code: taxableIncome <- taxable_income(gross, totalRelief) print(noquote(format(taxableIncome, big.mark = ",", scientific = FALSE))) #> [1] 381,600

title: Nigeria PIT Audit Guide
code: employeeLiability <- employee_tax_liability(taxableIncome, period ="yearly") print(noquote(format(employeeLiability, big.mark = ", ", scientific = FALSE))) #> [1] 74, 250.63

title: Consolidated Relief Allowance (CRA) — consolidated_relief
text: consolidated_relief() computes Consolidated Relief Allowance (CRA), key tax relief Nigeria’s Personal Income Tax Act (PITA) 2020.

title: Consolidated Relief Allowance (CRA) — consolidated_relief
code: consolidated_relief(gross_income, period = "yearly")

title: Consolidated Relief Allowance (CRA) — consolidated_relief
text: gross_income Numeric. income CRA computed, typically result gross_income(). period Character. period CRA calculated. Accepts "yearly" (default) "monthly".

title: Consolidated Relief Allowance (CRA) — consolidated_relief
text: numeric value representing Consolidated Relief Allowance (CRA).

title: Consolidated Relief Allowance (CRA) — consolidated_relief
text: CRA designed reduce taxable income individual, ensuring portion earnings exempt taxation applying income tax rates. According Section 33(1) PITA amended Finance Act 2020, Consolidated Relief Allowance (CRA) defined : "shall allowed consolidated relief allowance ₦200,000 subject minimum 1% gross income, whichever higher, plus 20% gross income. balance shall taxable accordance income table Sixth Schedule Act." means CRA computed using formula: $$   CRA =   \begin{cases}   \text{Gross Income} \times 20\% + 200,000, & \text{} 1\% \times \text{Gross Income} \leq 200,000 \\   \text{Gross Income} \times 20\% + 1\% \times \text{Gross Income}, & \text{} 1\% \times \text{Gross Income} > 200,000   \end{cases} $$ logic can also expressed Excel : CRA = (gross_income * 1% > 200000, gross_income * 1% + gross_income * 20%, 200000 + gross_income * 20%) R, implemented using ifelse() function.

title: Consolidated Relief Allowance (CRA) — consolidated_relief
code: # Example 1: If 1% of gross income is greater than 200,000 Naira consolidated_relief(5000000) #> [1] 1200000 # Returns: (1% * 5000000) + (20% * 5000000) = 50,000 + 1,000,000 = 1,050,000  # Example 2: If 1% of gross income is less than or equal to 200,000 Naira consolidated_relief(2000000) #> [1] 6e+05 # Returns: 200,000 + (20% * 2000000) = 200,000 + 400,000 = 600,000  # Example 3: Compute monthly CRA for a gross income of 3,600,000 Naira consolidated_relief(3600000, "monthly") #> [1] 756000 # 1% of 3,600,000 = 36,000 (greater than 16,666.67, so we take 36,000) # Monthly CRA = (36,000 + 20% * 3,600,000) = 36,000 + 720,000 = 756,000

text: Legal Basis: According Section 33(2) Personal Income Tax Act (PITA) 2020, taxpayers entitled various reliefs, including: Consolidated Relief Allowance (CRA) – Computed per PITA Section 33(2). Pension Contributions – Recognized tax-deductible item Pension Reform Act. National Housing Fund (NHF) Contributions – Exempt NHF Act. National Health Insurance Scheme (NHIS) Contributions – Exempt per NHIS Act. Computation Formula: $$   \text{Total Relief} = \text{CRA} + \text{Pension} + \text{NHF} + \text{NHIS} $$ Total Relief deducted Gross Income determine Taxable Income, subject personal income tax rates. Excel Equivalent Formula: Total_Relief = CRA + Pension + NHF + NHIS
